head.title: TV Remote Controlled Robots
head.subtitle: Robots from TV electronics and pizza boxes
head.description: Explore how with just a few lines of code and some basic electronic knowledge you can create your own remote controlled robot!

contents.contents: This was a project I did for a STEM festival while I was in college. I was with a team of people but, it seemed, I was the only one able to and willing to take the leadership position.

You have to understand. I was VERY poor. So, imagine a young and poor engineering college student looking around his apartment of old pizza boxes, rusted Arduinos, and scraps of wood. The only logical thing was to use what I had to build something fun.

The first step was to gather the supplies I needed. Because the robots really wouldn't be robots without a base, microcontroller, and a battery. Thankfully, the STEM festival allowed a certain amount of money to be refunded for purchases.
Now, that was essentially the limit of our spending. So I had to get creative.
I needed wheels. Wheels that could attach to the servo motors and had enouch traction to roll acrossed a gym floor.

So I had some old pizza boxes laying around that would serve as the center, old plastic strap that would wrap around the wheel for a smooth surface, and half used sandpaper to serve as the traction. And, of course, it was all secured down with hot glue and zip ties.
Next, I needed IR sensors and remote controllers to control them. By the grace of science, someone from across my apartment complex had thrown out 2 CRT monitor TV's with there remotes.

Now, if anyone else out there has tried to open a CRT monitor they would now that it's DAMN hard. But oh boy is there a treasure trove of trinkets and gizmos in there. People have even turned one into a makeshift oscilloscope!
